I agree with many other correspondents that some functions of government are best privatized and others done directly by government employees, but in either case government cannot abdicate its responsibility for monitoring results and ensuring the public gets good value for money. Privatization must be accompanied by an investment in evaluation by independent evaluators and complete transparency (and free competition) in the contracting process. Both bids and contracts should be posted on the Web and whistle-blowers should be celebrated and not persecuted.

The functions of government that should never be privatized are those that involve state-sanctioned violence, surveillance or any clandestine operations. No private prisons with armed guards, no Blackwater. The license to be violent in the name of the people should remain with the state alone. It is hard enough to hold our government to account for its use of violence and its invasions of privacy - it is virtually impossible with a private contractor.

Another aspect of privatization is the loss of the citizen's right to appeal. My experience is that public organizations in education, health care and other spheres of (formerly) government services have multi-step dispute resolution procedures that enable complainants to go up the line.

Privatized operators have but one client, the privatizing government and its contract. They aren't interested in complainants, unless the complainant is affluent enough to afford a lawyer, and one of the first things to go is the dispute resolution process.
In some Canadian provinces hospital cleaning was privatized. Wages and training fell as turnover soared. The net result was an explosion in multi-drug resistant pathogens from inadequate cleaning.

Canadian single payer health care, with the government as sole insurer for medically necessary services has overhead expenses of three per cent. In contrast, the supposedly more efficient private U.S. insurers have overhead greater than 20 per cent as they pay their executives hundreds of millions while denying services to the sick.

President Obama will rue the day he left out the public option in the Affordable Care Act. Public is the only option for affordable care.

It is always best when reading analysis by economists, particularly those at the Sloan School, that economics is not a science, even when the term is modified by "dismal." Productivity - and could the Times please commission the occasional article defining these terms - is not a form of natural law. It seems to me mostly a propaganda tool for the 1 percent to tell the 99 percent they should take a pay cut.

The problem in the Euro is its flawed political construction, a fact recognized by its architects 25 years ago. It was a political project whose aim was a more perfect union. The single currency was an initial success - by reducing the costs of foreign exchange in 17 currencies, it added significantly to eurozone GDP, and was remarkably popular but it was always more vulnerable to a major global shock than the U.S. economy because it did not have proper political structures to oversee the eurozone's economic machinery.

Relying on economists to describe the problem is like relying on obstetricians to describe Hodgkins Lymphoma. Basic medical training gives them the general vocabulary to diagnose but the vocabulary for treatment of the disease is probably a little beyond them.

The euro crisis is international, political, social and historical as well as economic. Productivity differences are but one part of the picture - and probably not the most important one.

Productivity means that people buy German cars, Italian cars, French cars, Swedish phones, but no one buys Greek or Spanish cars or phones.  We buy Greek and Spanish olive oil and vacations.  The labor required for producing olive oil or servicing tourists is far less skilled and less well-paid than for making cars and phones.  But the strength of the Euro allowed the waiters and olive-pickers to get loans to buy German cars.  Essentially, the strength of the German economy underwrote loans for Greeks to buy German goods, but that house of cards has collapsed.

One often reads, as here, that the disparity in productivity between northern Europe and Greece made the collapse of the Euro inevitable.  I've never understood this.   Couldn't - at least in principle  (!) - people in Greece live in two bedroom homes, with one TV and a Ford, and people in Germany in three bedroom homes, with two TVs and a Mercedes?   And couldn't that, theoretically, be stable?  Why does the difference in productivity force (like a law of nature) the collapse of the Euro.  The author writes that lest the economies had converged perfectly and soon in productivity, the Euro would collapse, but I don't see it.

Privatization may sometimes be appropriate or at least defensible. But far too often, privatization is about replacing public services with a crass form of white collar patronage in which wealthy CEOs and campaign donors get rich, while middle class jobs get replaced with minimum wage, no benefit privatized jobs.

As I noted in last night's comment on this same topic, there are three factors beyond sticker price to evaluate when considering privatization:

1. Service. While sometimes the profit motive provides better service, other times it can reduce the quality of service. When it comes to something like making sure prisoners don’t escape or our children get educated, poor quality and cutting corners can be costly.

2. Democracy. One reason for services to be public is to make sure everyone has access (such as with the Post Office), or to ensure that certain services aren’t provided excessively (such as with prisons). Privatization frequently undermines those goals.

3. Workers. Where privatization promises cost savings, it often comes from replacing middle class jobs with minimum wage jobs. But doing so is often not worth it in the long run, as such workers are more likely to need other government services and an economic of rich and poor is less vibrant than one with a stable middle class.

These factors demonstrates that privatization is often pure folly.

To seattle expat:

Actually, I'm a Tacoma expat, but going the other way (obviously in more ways than merely regional).

Your justifications may need freshening: in most states these days, and for awhile now, public sector workers are the best-paid block of workers in the state, well above private sector norms -- and this includes teachers.

Dealing with abusers IS easy. Now that this is out, the political pressure on Christie to disavow his former relationship and find another provider will be quite intense -- and if a reliable provider can't be found, he'll be under pressure to re-internalize the processes at question (prison half-way houses). As to the federal government dealing with financial services "abusers", their argument is that what was done often wasn't against the law -- and in any event it has nothing to do with privatization. You don't get to put the onus on me to prove that Christie's friends are "outliers" -- government at all levels privatizes many things, and the presumption is that they've done decent due diligence in their selections, and audit results. You apparently believe they're not "outliers", so you prove your contention.

I can buy much of your last paragraph, but there are those who argue that PARTS of those services can be privatized responsibly and at significant savings. But what I read is that the issue to liberals remains a conviction that people "own" these government jobs, and that they're being stolen from them. They don't own the jobs.

If jobs don't exist at least in part for the well-being of people who do them, then why do people work for pay? Are you suggesting slavery is the answer? If a job is worth doing, then it's worth paying people a decent wage and a pension. Pay people barely subsistence and treat them like dirt and watch the quality of the work go down.

My mother worked 30 years for New York State. She was paid very little for her office work, dealing with the public, and when she retired she received--wait for it---$900 a month pension! The horror! Of course she bought a McMansion and jetted to Vegas every month, and on your dime!!!

Sorry for the sarcasm, but the Republican talking point that all government employees are worthless obviously makes me furious.

A sensible people would look askance at any attempt to privatize what are normally considered government-provided services, unless quality, security and reliability (under supervision) can be credibly pitched at lower cost; and proved to be so over time. Those really should be the only criteria for privatizing.

But just as it's not an inherent right of the private sector to perform all the work in our society for a profit, it isn't an inherent right of people to seek and keep government jobs simply to keep them employed, regardless of the cost.

You're right, the Times has been vocal on this issue over the past few days, and I've read those pieces. What comes through clearly is a sense of outrage that the "jobs and benefits" of public sector employees are sacrificed to privatization schemes, and the worst outliers of abuse are given as justifying examples.

So, deal with the abusers, and make feasibility selection and on-going audit processes more robust, but don't tar all of privatizing because of your conviction that these jobs "belong" to public sector workers. They don't. Those jobs don't exist for the economic well-being of people who can seek to do the same things in the private sector if they wish, but would rather be employed by a governmental agency with compensation and benefits plans (including retirement) that bear no rational resemblance to what the rest of society gets.
